column1: aarontveitdaily 159471811083 "2017-04-12 00:52:35 GMT" http://aarontveitdaily.tumblr.com/post/159471811083/act-benefit-performance-and-gala-set-for-may-5-in "tveitnetwork: ACT â€“ A Contemporary Theater of Connecticut will hold its first benefit gala on May 5th at 7:30pm at the spectacular Vinoly home in Ridgefield. The evening will include an open bar
column2: hors d'oeuvres
column3: a silent and live auction
column4: and special performances by Broadway stars. Incredible performances by major stars will include; Stephen Schwartz (composer of Broadway shows Wicked
column8: and Children of Eden)  Aaron Tveit (Broadwayâ€™s Next to Normal
column11: as well as TVsâ€œGrease Liveâ€ and â€œGracelandâ€) Lindsay Mendez (Broadwayâ€™s Wicked
column14: and Significant Others) Kara Lindsay (Broadwayâ€™s Wicked and Newsies) Money raised through ticket sales and auction items will be used to renovate the ACT theatre on the old Schlumberger property
column15: as well as to launch youth programs and mainstage productions
column16: which will further elevate the arts and music in Ridgefield and surrounding communities. Â The ACT founders and Board of Directors anticipate a spectacularly entertaining and memorable evening. Please visit www.actofct.org to purchase tickets. ACT is a 501Â©(3) organization. About ACT of Connecticut A Contemporary Theatre (ACT) of Connecticut will take over the famous Schlumberger auditorium adding to the communityâ€™s anticipated cultural center that will span 30 acres of the former Schlumberger property. Produced and led by two accomplished theater professionals
column17: this contemporary theater is likely to be the regional theater destination theatergoers choose. ACT will present limited engagement runs of well-known Broadway plays and musicals
column18: as well as world premiere plays and musicals by the next generation of writers and composers. The theater company is expected to produce four shows per year
column19: with each show including Broadway professionals and Ridgefieldâ€™s professional actors and actresses. In addition to fully produced
column21: the producers will launch youth education classes
column24: and a conservatory program for high school students. ACT brings yet another level of artistic professionalism to Ridgefield along with the world renowned Aldrich Museum
column26: and The Ridgefield Playhouse. ACT co-founders
column27: Katie Diamond and Daniel C. Levine can be reached via email at actconnecticut@gmail.com. Please visit www.actofct.org for more information. (source) " False text

column1: aarontveitdaily 159300660213 "2017-04-07 13:24:14 GMT" http://aarontveitdaily.tumblr.com/post/159300660213/a-true-broadway-baby-aaron-tveit "tveitnetwork: Aaron Tveit is a man who can do it all. Not only has he toured the country with numerous shows including â€œRentâ€ and â€œHairspray

column4: and portrayed several characters on television such as â€œGossip Girl'sâ€ Tripp van der Bilt and â€œGraceland'sâ€ Mike Warren. Yes
column6: and he is coming to the Parker Playhouse in Fort Lauderdale on April 29 for a one night only concert. Prepare to see just how much he can dazzle an audience. First off
column7: what can we expect from your performance at the Parker Playhouse? Itâ€™s essentially an evening of Broadway songs. Iâ€™ve been doing some concerts lately
column8: and this is a show that I first did at a place called Wolf Trap outside of DC. So it is a relatively new one for me. Some of the songs will be from shows that Iâ€™ve been in
column9: some songs are favorites of mine
column10: and some songs you may not necessarily expect me to sing. So it is kind of an evening of Broadway songs
column11: a lot of which audiences will definitely recognize. Songs we would not expect you to sing? Any examples? Well
column12: I donâ€™t want to give anything away
column13: but the best example was when I did my first set of concerts a few years ago in New York. I had the idea to sing a Taylor Swift song. I try to have fun with these concerts and not take myself too seriously
column14: and my hope is the audience will feel the same way. So my music director and I went back and forth and we thought this could be the worst idea ever
column15: or it could be a great idea. I ended up singing â€œWe Are Never Ever Getting Back Together
column16: â€ and it ended up being of the most fun moments of the evening. The audience even participated. So from that experience
column17: with all the shows I put together
column18: I always look for a way to include the audience and have them be a little surprised by some of my song choices just for the goal of everyone having a good time. So that is kind of an example I can give without giving anything away. Iâ€™m assuming this is not your first time in Fort Lauderdale. I have spent a lot of time in Fort Lauderdale. One of the TV shows I was on
column20: â€ was shot in Florida so I was there for the better part of three years. I actually drove by the Parker Playhouse daily. What would you say is your favorite part about performing? The thing that I miss the most about being on stage since Iâ€™ve been doing a lot of TV and film primary for the last 5-6 years is the interaction with the audience. Thatâ€™s what these concerts
column21: kind of along the lines I was saying before about the songs that I look for
column22: they really allow me to break that fourth wall and directly interact with the audience. I like to speak to them. That is definitely the most rewarding to me. Having that back and forth with the audience. Being a vocalist
column23: Broadway star and a TV and film actor
column24: you are pretty much a triple threat! Do you prefer one more than the others? [Laughs] You know
column25: Iâ€™ve gotten to the point where I now love working on set and being on camera as much as I love singing. They kind of come hand in hand now. Iâ€™ve worked and fell in love with the craft of being on camera
column27: there is absolutely nothing like being on stage and having the energy of the audience. Having that back and forth. You know
column28: when youâ€™re shooting something on set
column30: nobody can laugh â€“ you get no feedback. I mean
column31: you might watching something a year later and say
column33: I kind of remember when we shot that
column34: â€ but itâ€™s very different. There is nothing like the energy of being on stage. Do you have a dream role? Thatâ€™s a hard one for me because Iâ€™ve been so blessed and lucky. Ever since I left school
column35: Iâ€™ve gotten to do so many different things in all these different avenues and I have thoroughly enjoyed every single second of it. So I think going forward
column36: I donâ€™t know if I can put a finger on what the dream role would be
column37: but I obviously just want the opportunities to continue. Thatâ€™s my dream to be able to keep this going for the rest of my career and get the same kind of fulfillment out of it. â€œRentâ€ kick started your career
column38: correct? Yes. Do you plan on seeing the 20th anniversary tour? I had a little bit of interaction with the people who were putting that tour together right before they were going out. One of my company managers was working on the production side of things
column39: so I was aware of it
column40: but I donâ€™t have any plans now. If they are close to anywhere that Iâ€™m at
column41: Iâ€™ll definitely check it out. The problem with those tours is that they donâ€™t play New York
column42: but Iâ€™ll check it out if itâ€™s playing anywhere Iâ€™m near. I actually did â€œRentâ€ at the Broward Center back in
column44: 2004. Nice! Well many people know you as Gabe from â€œNext to Normalâ€ since you originated that role. Out of every show you have done
column45: do you think that one had the biggest impact on audiences? It definitely
column47: had the biggest visceral response from an audience. I was just talking with someone today who didnâ€™t know anything about it
column48: and they were bawling in the theatre. That was the response from a lot of people. That show definitely struck a chord and I think whatâ€™s amazing
column50: is sometimes you donâ€™t go there completely with the subject matter on stage
column52: really went there. I think that was the ultimate success of the show. We put forward this very difficult topic and dealt with it. And it was incredibly rewarding for us. We worked on this show for a long time
column53: and even though it went through some changes
column54: it was well received. The run and the acclaim was very nice. Iâ€™m going to be nosy for a hot second. Do you currently have someone special in your life? I am dating. Iâ€™ve been seeing someone
column55: but itâ€™s still in an earlier place. Iâ€™m not in a serious
column59: correct? Yes. I am straight. So youâ€™re pretty much a disappointment to every gay fan you have. [Laughs] Yes
column60: but I very much appreciate their support and always have. Outside of performing
column61: what are some of your other hobbies and interests? I play a lot of golf. I actually played a lot when I lived in south Florida. I try to stay active. I play in two basketball leagues and two softball leagues here in New York. That was kind of my primary focus growing up. Itâ€™s nice to get away from the daily grind and do something that turns your mind off and lets you go somewhere else. I read a lot
column63: play video games. Iâ€™m not like a big go outer and partier
column64: so I look for things that kind of let me hit reset button on myself. I read that you are extensively involved with charity work and plan to partner with The First Tee this spring. Can you tell me more about that? Yes. I have not worked with them yet
column65: but we had a couple of things come through last year that Iâ€™m looking forward to. Itâ€™s our golf charity organization thatâ€™s an outreach program for underprivileged children that lets them get out on the golf course and teach them life values through the game. I think itâ€™s a really wonderful thing that they do. Iâ€™ve been a fan of their work for a long time
column66: and hopefully this spring I can meet some kids and work with them more actively. I also read that you turned down business scholarships to major in the arts at Ithaca College. Is that true? [Laughs] Yes. So where do you think you would be if you did not pursue acting? I donâ€™t know. Itâ€™s very interesting because I would have graduated college in 2005 and started working. When everything kind of tanked in 2008
column67: I was going to go to school for applied economics and be an investment banker
column68: I could have put in two years of 80 hour weeks and gotten fired. So itâ€™s very interesting. I thought I made a bold choice
column69: but maybe I made the safe choice. But who knows
column70: I always sang and always loved to sing and had a burning desire to do so. Maybe I would have ended up on â€œAmerican Idolâ€ or â€œThe Voice
column71: â€ one of those things if I was working in an office and unfulfilled. Do you currently have any other project in the works? Actually
column72: this is the first time in a long time I donâ€™t. Iâ€™ve been doing these shows and this is the first bit of time Iâ€™ve had off in a long
column74: so Iâ€™m totally open and looking for the next thing. Iâ€™ve been reading a lot of things and looking for whatever I do next to be great. I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s going to be in TV
